review_title: Mismanagement prevents teams from meeting their potential
pros: Many of the teams fully embrace remote work. I first started working 100% remotely many years before the pandemic.
cons: The software development teams I was a part of were terribly mismanaged. Managers made decisions re: product direction but didn't share this with the team responsible for the design, which led to lots of rework. Directors scared the staff so much that information wasn't shared upward and this contributed to our teams constantly missing release deadlines and delivering buggy products. Those of us who were passionate about delivering a quality product for our customers were treated poorly. In general, women were treated as second class citizens. I believe the benefits at NTT do not compare well to those provided at other employers. Note that this is a very large company and I believe some associates have had better experiences on different teams.

review_title: Ok if no other option available
pros:
- average good salary if you work with them as an individual contractor
- nice office spaces
cons:
- No promotion plan at all, you get to switch positions only if you know the right people, no matter how good you are
- they don't care if your performances are high, becuase of the lack of any kind of promotion plan
- no real development plan, it's up to you if you feel the need to do some training outside the company, they might pay for it 
- Structure is rigid with a lot of pyramidal management departments, who are unqualified and which are rather Messengers for the higher management. Their main tasks are checking timesheets accuracy and making sure you remain the perfect slave
- Low salaries with almost no option for getting an increase 
- Payment gets fairly better only if you work with them as an individual Contractor. They offer this option to you if you want to earn more than 2k eur / month. But even so, payment is similar to other companies who would pay you the same amount but as their employee
- No bonuses or worth mentioning benefits (you get some discounts with some companies) 
- company gear (laptops, screens etc) are outdated and from the lower price range

review_title: TLDR - Do Not Try To Work Here Unless It's Short Term! (Consulting business review)
pros:
1. There's real consulting experience to be gained here if you sell yourself well and network appropriately.

2. Leadership change improved company outlook (slightly)

3. Pay is average for the industry

4. Benefits are so-so
cons:
1. Book of business generally ranges from non-existent to average at best. Most clients are located in or around where their HQ 

2. Regionally speaking, business is weak pretty much everywhere else

3. Book of business is barren first and last months of the year. This puts a tremendous amount of pressure on consultants

4. Minimal bench time before they lay you off. EOY is usually when business is slow and staff are usually sweating and hoping they either stay billable or become billable before their bench time ends

4. Your seniority/tenure here means nothing. Over here, your relationship with upper management is more important than the value you bring to the table/clients 

5. Do not waste your time here unless you just need a paycheck, something short-term, or need a stepping stone to a better consulting firm. Huge waste if this is your first job out of grad school. Even if you get in, it's entirely possible to only be working on staff aug type work

6. You do not want to work here

7. Repeat #6 and move on

review_title: Good Culture, Worst Management I’ve Ever Seen
pros: Culture is great, people support each other and they somewhat care about their employees (life insurance, transportation, food subsidy, etc)
cons: Management does not care about your career goals or career path, they only care about the client giving them money. If you want to change roles, they are not going to help you unless you give them an ultimatum, but this at the end will finish in you resigning.

pros:
If you are a "net new" employee you are most likely young, inexperienced and come "cheap" and you're glad for the work. 

If you have experience, you most likely had an "in" with someone within NTT and managed to push a reasonable compensation package.
cons:
NTT is focused on the bottom line. Each quarter revenue margin is determined and resource cuts are made regardless of the impact to services from the paying customers. 

Job security doesn't exist. If you work for NTT over the years, don't expect reasonable pay increases, even if you have merit, increased revenue and established relationships with customers that promote the company.

NTT Data doesn't have much focus or concern on employees regardless of the lip service. However, much of their business is resource driven because humans do the work- so it doesn't make sense. If there's a change in a contract or a customer ramps down, employees are not told until they are notified they have 1 week to find something else within NTT or they will be fired.

If you have other employer options if NTT offers you a job, seriously consider them ... or be willing to be looking for a job at a moment's notice. Also, the only way to really get a "real" pay raise from NTT is to leave the company. Bonus is imaginary. They may tempt you and say you'll get 10%, 15% or 20% bonus but that is only if they want to give it to you. There is no real guarantee of the bonus even if you generate review and exceed performance. If you feel you need a job with NTT, make sure your base pay is "enough".

review_title: Seemed like a good job until it wasn’t
pros: They gave me bench pay for 2 months after my contract with Thermo Fisher
cons: After I told my actual boss at NTT about what was going on with my coworker who was pretending to be my boss and who was rarely actually at work, they did nothing to him and instead didn’t argue my case with Thermo Fisher and allowed me to be fired. They kept me on the bench and even tried to get me to work for Alabama Unemployment, but since that was a departure from my role as an IT professional, I declined and they let me go. In the agreement they made me sign, they said they would pay for my benefits for the first month and a half and not stop me from getting unemployment. They lied. They told unemployment that I was let go due to constant absences. That was my coworker, not me. Luckily unemployment still came through eventually, but they also cut my benefits off immediately and I had to threaten to Sue them to get what they promised in their agreement. I was there every day until I got sick. I did everything because my coworker was lame and didn’t show up to work 70% of the time.

pros: Compensation and benefits are quite reasonable.
cons:
Many false promises were made during the interview phase. From education and career development to the types of projects one would be working on. Working here honestly feels like are just another employee number - I doubt most people even know each other's names.

During my interview I was promised lots of career development and education opportunity. What this turned out to be was forced "educational hour" that must be completed each year in order to qualify for a raise. You get to pick from an online library that has courses of little value. As they also want me to be 100% billable to the client I was told the forced 25 hours must be completed on my own time.

You are also partnered with a career advisor that is supposed to help you plan goals and achieve some growth in the company. These goals also determine if you get a raise. Well, in one year I have seen my CA one time and I was the one who had to reach out and start the process. Again, a failed promise that was never delivered.

Overall, it feels like I am just a number that needs to remain billable. Nothing that was promised in my interview ever came to fruition.

review_title: OK start to career, depending on the team
job_title: Computer Information Systems Analyst in Arlington, VA
pros:
Your experience here greatly depends on who you are working with - both departmentally and client-wise. This is an okay place to start for those without experience. You will be thrown into the deep end and expected to learn and do everything on your own from day one. You will develop a lot of skills that you can take elsewhere. 

- Great clients to work with. 
- Wonderful and collaborative co-workers, depending on the team.
- Ability to work with a lot of other teams.
- Will be pushed to learn new skills through experience.
cons:
A pro and a con - you will be thrown into the deep end and expected to learn and do everything on your own from day one. Management seems to care more about you completing the work than ensuring that the work is of quality and that you learned to do things the correct way. 

- Unorganized management.
- A lot of work for little recognition. 
- Very minimal bonuses. 
- Small amount of upward growth. 
- Will often be asked to do things that is beyond your job description and above your pay grade.
- Leadership can be clique-y.
- Sometimes, management cares more about furthering their own careers rather than benefiting the client.
- Corporate IT team takes a really long time to respond to inquiries and will call you in the middle of the night instead of during a time you are available. For the most part, you have to be in Internet Explorer and everything takes a really long time to load, making everything to do with internal IT a huge hassle.

During my time here, I felt discriminated against by another member of my team because of my gender. They would openly treat members of their same gender better than me and question everything I did as if I was incompetent and unable to do my job, despite having the most experience and providing the most value to the customer. This occurred in public spaces that my managers were able to see and did not take action on and I did not feel supported at all by my team. It got to the point where I dreaded coming to work every single day and managers were turning blind eyes to their teams. I was the only member on my team that was my gender and felt that the teams I worked with internally lacked diversity. 

I felt often that my opinions were not valued learned a lot about the kind of leader I would not want to be.
